importantTimeframes.approximateTimeFrameStart: shortly after the world's most-visited museum opened on Sunday morning
importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The robbery occurred during opening hours, and experts believe the stolen items may have been disposed of or sold within just two days, making immediate recovery efforts critical.

keyTakeAways: A daylight robbery at the Louvre in Paris involved four masked thieves who used power tools to breach the museum in less than eight minutes.

The stolen jewellery, estimated at €88 million, includes historically significant pieces such as a diamond and emerald necklace given by Napoleon I to his wife, a tiara worn by Empress Eugenie, and items once owned by Queen Marie-Amelie.
A damaged crown belonging to Empress Eugenie was found on the thieves' escape route, indicating the heist was executed with haste.
The thieves used a truck with a mechanical lift to access the Galerie d'Apollon via a balcony near the River Seine, and two of them cut through a glass window using a battery-powered disc cutter.
The vehicle was initially set on fire, but staff prevented the attempt, and the thieves escaped on scooters.
Security flaws were exposed: one in three rooms lacked CCTV, and the main alarm system failed to activate, leading officials to blame protocol failures.
French President Emmanuel Macron described the heist as an attack on France's cultural heritage.
Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin criticized the failure of security protocols, stating that the thieves' ability to drive a modified truck to the museum created a 'terrible image' for France.
Experts believe the stolen items are likely already broken down into precious metals and gems, smuggled out of the country and sold for a fraction of their value.
Prosecutor Laure Beccuau emphasized that the true loss is not just financial but to France's historical legacy, and warned that melting the jewels would result in a loss of value to the robbers.
Investigators suspect a team of professionals due to the speed, organization, and technical precision of the heist.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a daring daylight robbery at the Louvre museum in Paris, four masked thieves used a modified truck with a mechanical lift and a battery-powered disc cutter to breach the Galerie d'Apollon in under eight minutes. The stolen items—valued at €88 million—include historically significant pieces such as a diamond and emerald necklace from Napoleon I, a tiara from Empress Eugenie, and items once owned by Queen Marie-Amelie. A damaged crown belonging to Empress Eugenie was found on the escape route, indicating haste. Security flaws, including the absence of CCTV in one in three rooms and a failed alarm system, were cited by officials. French President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin condemned the heist as an attack on national heritage and criticized the failure of security protocols. Experts believe the stolen jewellery has likely been broken down into precious metals and gems, smuggled abroad, and sold for a fraction of its value. The French government has since tightened security measures around cultural sites. Prosecutor Laure Beccuau emphasized that the true loss lies in the erosion of France's historical legacy, not just the financial value.
title: Louvre heist: Stolen jewellery worth €88m, prosecutor says
